clinical_study.brief_title: The Potentially Addictive Properties of Soda: A Feasibility Study
clinical_study.official_title: The Potentially Addictive Properties of Soda: A Feasibility Study

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study to investigate the addictive properties of soda and other sugar sweetened beverages (SBBs) in teenagers aged 13-18 years. It is hypothesized that participants who were regularly consuming sweetened and caffeinated beverages will experience symptoms typical of caffeine withdrawal, such as headache and fatigue, during the SSB withdrawal period.

primary_outcome.description: Symptoms of withdrawal during the SSB withdrawal period (days 6-8) will be compared to symptoms of withdrawal during usual consumption period (days 1-3). Three measures are used to assess withdrawal symptoms: Griffiths' withdrawal scale, the relative reinforcing value of soda, and daily check in questions on well-being.

secondary_outcome.description: Changes in diet will be assessed by 24-hour dietary recalls and beverage recalls
Impulsivity will be assessed via the delayed discounting task
Stress will be assessed via salivary cortisol samples
Preference for soda will be measured through the Labeled Affective Magnitude Scale (LAMS) and daily check-in questions

other_outcome.measure: Compliance with intervention to only drink water and unflavored milk during the SSB withdrawal phase
other_outcome.description: Using measure of salivary caffeine, beverage recalls, and 24-hour dietary recalls, we will assess compliance.

intervention.description: During days 1-5, participants will drink the beverages they normally consume (no intervention). On days 6-8, participants will be instructed to drink only water and unflavored milk during the withdrawal period (days 6-8).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Drinks more than 36 ounces of sugar-sweetened beverages per day
- Speaks fluent English
- Parent speaks English or Spanish
- Lives in San Francisco Bay Area
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant or nursing
- Taking medication to address mental health issues
